â   â
[[File:Deweytruman12.jpg|thumb|right|The [[United States presidential election, 1948]] was a famous example of an upset victory. [[Harry Truman]]'s unexpected victory caused one newspaper to run the wrong headline.]]
 
An '''upset''' occurs in a [[competition]], frequently in [[election|electoral]] [[politics]] or [[sports]], when the party popularly expected to win (the favorite), is defeated by an [[underdog (competition)|underdog]] whom the majority expects to lose, defying the [[conventional wisdom]]. The underdog then becomes a '''[[Goliath|giant-killer]]'''.
An '''upset''' occurs in a [[competition]], frequently in [[election|electoral]] [[politics]] or [[sports]], when the party popularly expected to win (the favorite), is defeated by an [[underdog (competition)|underdog]] whom the majority expects to lose, defying the [[conventional wisdom]]. The underdog then becomes a '''[[Goliath|giant-killer]]'''.
